entry.title: Re: Post internal expenses (like repair expense) to AUC w...
entry.content:
Good day @Purandar 

Thank you for your question.

Have a look at the following references for more details.

Posting Post-Capitalization, External Asset Acquisitions, Assets Under Construction: Management and Settlement, Transferring Assets Under Construction

Please note that you must post all asset through a subledger controlled process. This is why you cannot use Post General Journal Entries to credit expense and debit AUC.

In summary, because G/L accounts are asset reconciliation accounts, the public cloud due to its clean-core principles, does not allow you to post project costs manually to an AUC through journal entries. However, you can either use Post Capitalization or Asset Acquisition apps to achieve your goal of debiting the AUC and crediting expense G/L accounts without requiring vendor or PO data. That means after you complete your project, you settle the AUC to the final intangible asset using standard settlement app.

Have a look at Blog: Post-Capitalization in Asset Accounting for some more details.

Let me know if you have further questions.

 

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Build 8228/8229 Enhancements To Unload/Reload DB Lowe...
entry.content: Chris, thanks for the reply. I didn't quite clarify well in my OP, we did confirm that there were no unintended deletes, so that's obviously the most important thing. I was able to reproduce what I encountered. Grabbed a backup (12.8 GB DB / 790 MB LOG) that was previously running on Build 8039. Put the same build on a server we weren't using and re-executed the same deletes. The difference seems to be whether or not I stop our SQL Anywhere Windows Service before unloading and reloading, and I'm honestly surprised I've never noticed this before, or I'm just forgetting because I typically will stop the service beforehand. After re-executing the deletes, the source DB grew to 16.7 GB DB / 1.87 GB LOG. Immediate unload/reload into a new DB gives me a 6.4 GB DB. Stopped the service, source DB dropped to 12.9 GB DB / 1.87 GB LOG. Started service back up, did unload/reload again which gives me 4.4 GB. So, I guess, totally different question now - Why the different behavior after restarting the Windows service?

entry.title: Re: Migrating to Crystal 64-bit questions
entry.content:
Just one small addition: The later versions of Visual studio does not take the old APIs insistence on byte padding so to compile under VS2022 you need to do this:

#pragma pack(push, 8 )

#include <windows.h>

#pragma pack(pop)

#include "ufls/ufdllunicode.h"

#include "ufmain.h" #etc

That sets the packing to windows default which is 8 and then back to 1

entry.title: BiWhy ‚Äì OS Monitoring and BOBJ Metrics Synergy
entry.content:
Disclaimer:
BiWhy is available again for FREE to everyone on biwhy.net

During a system health check, we observed that BiPrecalculation.exe was the largest memory consumer, and its memory usage continuously increased without being released.
BOBJ metrics confirmed that the load was not growing, which strongly indicated a memory leak.

We warned the customer that servers running AO jobs might eventually run out of memory and proposed a simple workaround.

Workaround:
Reduce the parameter that automatically restarts the process after a specified number of processed requests.

3274298 - High memory consumption of BiPrecalculation.exe

https://me.sap.com/notes/3274298

 

Proper solution:
Open an SAP incident to fix the memory leak.

Unfortunately, the recommendations were not implemented, and exactly one year later the customer returned with the issue: their servers were running out of memory, just as predicted ‚Äì though this time the issue was resolved quickly.

Screenshots:

Content

  • BiPrecalculation.exe memory usage
  • Host memory impact caused by BiPrecalculation.exe
  • Requests to AO job process
  • AO jobs
  • Requests-per-process limit

 

BiPrecalculation.exe memory usage

Host memory impact caused by BiPrecalculation.exe

entry.title: Struggling with GR/IR Differences during Invoice posts? Use the Invoice Posting Analysis report
entry.content:
Hey All,
 
Handling GR/IR (WRX) issues can be challenging, especially when unexpected balances appear after posting logistics invoice verification documents.
 
As someone who works closely with global support teams and customer scenarios, I see the same pattern: customers spend significant time trying to understand how SAP calculated the WRX (GR/IR clearing) amount.

 

The good news?
SAP provides a helpful analysis tool that is still not widely known:
üëâ Invoice Posting Analysis report: IV_WRX_ANALYSIS
 
This report is described in SAP Note 2427297 - Analysis report to explain GR/IR amount (WRX line item), and in this blog, I want to make it simple, visual, and practical, so more customers can use it with confidence.



What the Invoice Posting Analysis Report Does
 
The Invoice Posting Analysis report (IV_WRX_ANALYSIS) explains how the system calculated the amount posted to the GR/IR clearing account (transaction key WRX) during Logistics Invoice Verification.
 
It explains the logic for material and planned delivery costs items. The document types that can be analyzed are:
- Invoices
- Credit memos
- Subsequent debits
- Subsequent credits
- Account maintenance documents including documents with multiple account assignment
 
This makes it an extremely valuable tool when:
- You see a difference between the goods receipt and the invoice
- The WRX amount is not what you expected
- The invoice hits unexpected accounts
- You need to explain the calculation to business users or auditors



What the Report Does Not Cover
 
To set the right expectations, the report does not explain calculations for:
- Unplanned delivery cost
- Taxes in the WRX line
- Foreign currencies
- Account maintenance documents for account-assigned purchase orders
- Contract invoices
- Direct postings to material or G/L accounts
- It also does not explain the amounts calculated for price difference (PRD/KBS) or exchange rate difference (KDM) postings
 
If your case falls into one of these categories, you may still need a deeper analysis.
 
 
How to Implement the Report (Manual Installation)
 
Because Note 2427297 does not contain SNOTE correction instructions, the report must be implemented manually.

 

‚úîÔ∏èSteps to Implement:
1. Go to transaction SE38 or SE80.
2. Create the following includes exactly with these names:
- IV_WRX_ANALYSIS
- IV_WRX_ANALYSIS_TOP
3. Copy the source code from the attachments in Note 2427297 into the respective includes.
4. Activate both includes.

 

üîîTip:
If you have already implemented an older version of the report, simply replace the existing code with the latest version from the Note.
 
Once activated, you can run the report IV_WRX_ANALYSIS using the SE38 transaction.
 
 
How to Run and Use the Report
 
1Ô∏è‚É£ Execute the Report
Go to transaction SE38 ‚Üí enter IV_WRX_ANALYSIS ‚Üí Execute.
 
2Ô∏è‚É£Enter the Selection Criteria
You only need three inputs:
- Document Number
- Fiscal Year
- Document Item
 
 
This makes it quick and simple to use, even during high-pressure situations like month-end closing.
 
3Ô∏è‚É£Analyze the Output
The report displays three clear sections:
 
A) Invoice & PO Details
All relevant information the system considered for the calculation, such as:
- PO details: Net Value, Net Price, Quantity
- Invoice and Goods Receipt details (depending on the formula used and the scenario)
 
B) Calculation Logic
This is the heart of the report.
It shows:
- The formula used by the system
- All values used in the calculation (GR quantities, invoice amounts, and condition values for each account)
- The final calculated WRX (GR/IR) amount
 
This transparency makes it much easier to verify whether the calculated value is correct.
 
Important Note: You will see the calculated value of the GR/IR (WRX) clearing account posted during the Invoice Receipt process.
 
C) Documentation
A helpful reference section with links to related information.
 

Image/data in this blog is from SAP internal systems, sample data, or demo systems. Any resemblance to real data is purely coincidental.

Why You Should Use This Report
 
The Invoice Posting Analysis report is one of the most effective tools for:
- Understanding complex WRX postings
- Reducing investigation time during closing
- Preparing clear explanations for business users, auditors, or finance teams
- Preventing unnecessary support cases
 
Still, many customers are not aware that this report exists, which is why I wanted to bring visibility to it!



Final Recommendation
 
If you work with Invoice Verification, other Procurement areas, or Finance, I highly encourage you to:
‚úîÔ∏èImplement the report manually (it only takes a few minutes)
‚úîÔ∏èUse it for each case where WRX amounts look unexpected
‚úîÔ∏èShare the Note 2427297 with your internal teams
‚úîÔ∏èAttach the report output when creating SAP Support cases
 
It will save you time, prevent misunderstandings, and bring full clarity to your GR/IR calculations.
 
If you have questions, need help implementing the report, or want to share feedback, feel free to leave a comment below.
 
It was nice to connect with you again üòâ
 
Best regards,
Carla Bussolo

entry.title: SAP Sales & Service Cloud V2 + ESM - API Authentication Methods
entry.content:
This blog explores the authentication methods available for SAP Sales & Service Cloud V2 APIs, especially when integrating with BTP, S4 HANA, external systems, ESM platforms.

Basic Authentication

Basic Authentication uses a username and password encoded in Base64. While simple, it is not recommended for production due to security risks unless combined with HTTPS.

GET {{url}}/sap/c4c/api/v1/iam-service/token
Content-Type: application/json
Authorization: Basic {{username}}:{{password}}

another API endpoint for token generate

GET {{url}}/auth/token
Content-Type: application/json
Authorization: Basic {{username}}:{{password}}

Refresh Token

once the token is expired and you can refersh the token

GET {{url}}/auth/token?grant_type=refresh_token
Content-Type: application/json
Authorization: Bearer {{accessToken}}

Use the token in API requests (Authorization: Bearer <token>).

Password Authentication 

Steps to follow

  • Go to System Settings - Search for Integration
  • Create a New Communication System and Select Inbound
  • Enter the Display ID, Description and set the password (minimum 30chars)

Once activated, you will see userName which be same as DisplayID  you entered and password which is been set by you.

GET {{url}}/auth/token
Content-Type: application/json
Authorization: Basic {{username}}:{{password}}

Use the token in API requests (Authorization: Bearer <token>).

OAuth2 SAML Bearer Assertion Flow

The following steps describe how to connect a SAP Sales Cloud Version 2 and SAP Service Cloud Version 2 system using the OAuth2 SAML Bearer Assertion Authentication flow. In this flow, the user identity of the logged-in user from source system can be propagated to SAP Sales and Service Cloud Version 2 system.

Steps to follow

  1. Login to your SAP BTP cockpit, and navigate to BTP Subaccount - Destinations  -  Download Trust
  2. Copy contents of the certificate between the header and the footer.

After export of the certificate, you will copy the certificate to cleartext and make below API call

POST {{url}}/sap/c4c/api/v1/iam-service/oauth2InboundConfiguration
Content-Type: application/json
Authorization: Basic {{user}}:{{password}}

{
    "id": "34f8b9d2-78c2-4617-bcf2-6eb36403c667",
    "clientAppName" : "<give your own name>",
    "certificate" : "MIIG7jCCBNagAwIBAXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXIe7+C/vwsdA="
}

Verify if your tenant is already configured.. </id> will have to be copied from above request which you passed in POST request

GET {{url}}/sap/c4c/api/v1/iam-service/oauth2InboundConfiguration/34f8b9d2-78c2-4617-bcf2-6eb36403c667
Content-Type: application/json
Authorization: Basic {{user}}:{{password}}

Use the token in API requests (Authorization: Bearer <token>).

OAuth2 JWT Bearer Assertion Flow

< This will be updated shortly>

 

Scopes

Scope is a mechanism in OAuth 2.0 to limit an application's access to a user's account. An OAuth 2.0 scope represents a list of resources that can be accessed by remote applications. They provide a way to limit the amount of access that is granted to an access token. For example, an access token issued to a client app may be granted READ and WRITE access to protected resources, or just READ access. You can implement your APIs to enforce any scope or combination of scopes you wish. So, if a client receives a token that has READ scope, and it tries to call an API endpoint that requires WRITE access, the call will fail.

OAuth2 Scope

while performing any API calls using OAuth2 token, you must need to check the Scope to see the permissions for different entities.. (READ or WRITE or both)

GET {{url}}/sap/c4c/api/v1/iam-service/oauth2Scope
Content-Type: application/json
Authorization: Bearer {{accessToken}}

Check the individual scope which your external API is been used.

GET {{url}}/sap/c4c/api/v1/iam-service/oauth2Scope/<id>
Content-Type: application/json
Authorization: Bearer {{accessToken}}

entry.title: Re: Instance Refresh Tool and New Learning Experience in...
entry.content:
@rahulbarvebd wrote:

Hello SAP Community,

We are planning an instance refresh for our SuccessFactors Learning (LMS) development and QA environments and have a few questions related to the process and the New Learning Experience:

  1. Is a customer with VSaaS LMS eligible to use the Instance Refresh Tool (IRT)?
  2. If eligible, can the tool be used for both BizX and LMS instances?
  3. During the instance refresh (manual or via IRT), will the new custom contents (such as custom cards, pages, and banners) that are part of the New Learning Experience in the source system replace those in the target system?
  4. Will the email notification templates in the source instance overwrite those in the target instance?
  5. Any additional information or best practices related to the New Learning Experience and instance refresh would be greatly appreciated.

Looking forward to your insights and experiences!

 

1. IRT is supported for VSaaS tenants as of 2H 2025. Blog-> Instance Refresh Tool (self-service Refresh) 1H202... - SAP Community

2. Yes, it can be used for both BizX & LMS.

3. Yes, New Learning Experience content in Target should get overwritten by the same from source.

4. Yes, email templates in target should get overwritten by the same from source.

5. You can refer to this KBA for general recommendations-> 2165346 - Learning Management System Manual Refresh Process

entry.title: Re: SAP SF LMS Item/class assignment
entry.content:
Hi @gopher93 

Please note that users cannot self-enroll into Items / Classes unless the Item and Class belong to a Library that the user has access to. Also, Classes can only be added to Libraries that the Item already belongs to.

This is the application's expected behavior: https://me.sap.com/notes/0002394095 

To have a different system behavior, it would be possible to have an enhancement request created for it (as per KBA 2090228), where the Learning Product Management team can further review and assess the requested functionality to be considered in a future release.

Best regards,

entry.title: Re: Getting Started with SAP IBP New Harmonized Planning Area (SAPIBP2)
entry.content:
hi,

we have many Excel files stored in SharePoint.
These files keep changing daily, and you need to bring this updated data into Datasphere every day.

Till now, we used an Open Connector in BTP Integration Suite to pull data from SharePoint ‚Üí Datasphere.

But now:
Open Connectors will be stopped (deprecated) in 2026.
So we need another standard and supported way

entry.title: Re: Programs , content and SCORMs mass load
entry.content:
Hi @baoyk 

Regarding a tool to mass import programs, currently there is no such tool available within SAP SF LMS. There have been some enhancements requests on it, and customers are welcomed to vote for any open requests and/or create additional ones. For example:

  • HAVING A POSSIBILITY TO MASS UPLOAD PROGRAMS

For more details on enhancement requests, please check the KBA 2090228. In addition to this, your team may also check the possibility of a custom solution, by engaging your company's Partner and/or SAP Professional Services team (KBA 2149831).

Now, regarding the content objects (SCORM, .pdf, .ppt, etc.), it's possible to upload them directly into the SFTP and then massively create the content records within LMS via Item Connector:

  • 2568384 - How to mass upload content files to iContent and create entities?

However, please note that Learning connectors can import thousands of entities in the system, so it's highly recommend that customers engage with our Professional Services organization or a certified Learning implementation partner before attempting to use connectors or any data import.

  • Import Data to SAP SuccessFactors Learning

Best regards,

entry.title: Re: OOALV Implementation of Checkbox Click Event Issue
entry.content:
Hi, 

Can you try adding the below?

" After updating GT_ALV
LOOP AT er_data_changed->mt_good_cells ASSIGNING FIELD-SYMBOL(<fs_change>)
WHERE fieldname = 'SEL'.

READ TABLE gt_alv ASSIGNING FIELD-SYMBOL(<fs_real>) INDEX <fs_change>-row_id.
IF sy-subrc = 0.
<fs_change>-value = <fs_real>-sel. " reflect real status
ENDIF.
ENDLOOP.


er_data_changed->refresh = 'X'.


er_data_changed->modify_cell(
i_row_id = ls_mod-row_id
i_fieldname = 'SEL'
i_value = ls_alv-sel ).


IF go_alv IS BOUND.
DATA(ls_stable) = VALUE lvc_s_stbl( row = 'X' col = 'X' ).
go_alv->refresh_table_display( is_stable = ls_stable ).
ENDIF.

------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Learn more about the SAP Support user and program here.

entry.title: Re: What is SAP Analytics Cloud preview tenant?
entry.content:
1- what is this preview tenant is meant for?
    A Preview tenant is a non-productive test environment that receives updates before they are released to general production tenants. It allows customers to test and evaluate new features in advance to ensure a smooth transition when the updates are eventually rolled out to their live system.
    These tenants are not meant for production work and are updated at a more frequent rate, such as bi-weekly or monthly, depending on the customer's release cycle. 
    Key characteristics of an SAC Preview tenant
2- Can this be used for POC's or sandbox?
    It was designed specifically for the scenario described above.

entry.title: Re: How to plan revenue in SAP S4 hana public cloud, for...
entry.content:
For Enterprise Projects in Public Cloud you need to use Financial Plan upload for all costs and revenues.  The both use category PLN.  Make sure the revenue is a negative amount.  And make sure all of your G/L accounts are in the correct G/L Account Hierarchy for EBRR and reporting to work.

I attached a screenshot of an upload file that worked.

entry.title: Safety Stock Behavior in V2 Reorder Point Planning ‚Äì Exclude from Available Stock Consumption
entry.content:
Hello All,

System : S4 HANA Public cloud

I am using MRP Type V2 (Automatic Reorder Point Planning) with lot size EX and a rounding value of 660. After the forecast calculation, the system proposed a reorder point of 869 and a safety stock of 515( service level 99.9%). Currently, safety stock is treated as a requirement and reduces the available stock, which prevents customer orders from consuming the available quantity. I want safety stock to be excluded from consuming available quantity. (refer screen shot)

My availability check (SR) is set to include safety stock, and even if I untick this option, the system behaves the same way. I do not want to manually remove safety stock from the material master.

Is there a way to achieve this without removing the safety stock indicator in the MRP type config? If I remove it, will the calculation differs? Or it just uses the safety calculation in the background and doesnt show or update in the material master ?

Thanks

entry.title: Re: U.S SECURE 2.0 Act - Section 603
entry.content:
@Euna Thank you  for quick response.  Do you have one combined plan or do you have multiple plans?

We have a combined plan that includes 401(k), Roth, and Catch-Up, and we are currently encountering issues with the system behavior.

Configuration: V_74FH_C  :Qualified plan , V_74FH_C :total max :23500. 

VV_T5F99K2_US_BN603 :ROLL

V_T7USBEN03 :  

BC31 and BC32  copied and assigned as below. 

Scenario 1:Employe have Pre tax 25 % and Post tax 20% in IT0169 and last year earning are $176 000 (WT/TB6)  please check below calculation.

In PP03, the employee reaches the 402(g) limit and the excess Roth deduction is not correctly moves to Section 603 Roth Catch-Up.

However, in PP04, only Pre-Tax continues ( 25%) to calculate and redirect to 603. Roth(20%) is no longer calculated nor redirected to Section 603, even though there is still available catch-up capacity.

PP01   
33826.65*25% 8456.66 
33826.65*20%6765.33 
 15221.99 
PP2  
15826.65*25%3956.66 
15826.65*20%3165.33 
 7121.99 
PP2 Limit 22343.98 
 23500 
23500-22343.981156.02 
PP3  
3826.65*25%956.66956.66+199.36=1156.02
3826.65*20%765.33765.33-199.36=565.97
 199.36 only this is the deduction on PP03
PP4  
23826.65*25%5956.66Only Pre-tax is calculated 
23826.65*20%4765.33Post tax is not calculated.

Scenario 2: 

Employee contributes only Roth : 25% ( IT0169) . When annual  limit of 23,500 is reached, SAP stops calculating Roth instead of moving the excess to Section 603 Roth Catch-Up. 

This behavior is not aligned with the Secure 2.0 pivot design, where both Pre-Tax and Roth contributions should automatically redirect to 603 Catch-Up once the limit is reached.

I raised a ticket with SAP, and they advised us to check the ROTH indicator in V_74FH_C. However, when I enable the Roth option, the Pre-Tax amount is not calculating.

My question is:
Do we need to create separate plans, or should this functionality work with a combined 401(k) plan? Has anyone encountered this issue with combined plans, and if so, how was it resolved?

Thank you 

Suneetha

entry.title: Re: SAP SuccessFactors Implementation: Module Sequence and Logic
entry.content: For a successful Core HR implementation, it is advisable for the client to conduct a design workshop to clearly define and scope process requirements. ‚Ä¢‚Äú‰ªÖÈôêÊ≠£ÂÄº‚Äù‚ÄìÂ¶ÇÊûú‰ΩøÁî®Ê≠§ÈÄâÈ°πÔºåÁ≥ªÁªüÂ∞Ü‰ªÖÊòæÁ§∫ÊâÄÈÄâÂá≠ËØÅÈ°πÁõÆÂú®Ê≠£ÂÄºÊÉÖÂÜµ‰∏ãÁöÑÊÄªËÆ°„ÄÇÂê¶ÂàôÔºåÊ≠§È°πÁõÆÁöÑÈáëÈ¢ùÁ≠â‰∫éÈõ∂„ÄÇ

3)Â¶ÇÊûúÈúÄË¶ÅÈÄöËøáÊñá‰ª∂ÈìæËøΩË∏™Áé∞ÈáëÊµÅÁõÆÁöÑÂπ∂ËøΩÊ∫ØÊ∏ÖÁÆóÂÖ≥Á≥ªÔºåÈúÄË¶ÅÂú®ÈÖçÁΩÆÁÇπ‚ÄúÂÆö‰πâÁé∞ÈáëÊµÅÊä•Ë°®ÁâàÊú¨‚ÄùÔºàID 105331Ôºâ‰∏≠ÈÖçÁΩÆÊâÄÊúâË¥¶Êà∑Á±ªÂûãÔºöÁé∞ÈáëË¥¶Êà∑„ÄÅÊäµÈîÄË¥¶Êà∑ÂíåÂèëÁ•®Ë¥¶Êà∑„ÄÇÂØπ‰∫éÊäµÈîÄË¥¶Êà∑ÔºàË¥¶Êà∑Á±ªÂûãÔºâÔºåÊÄªË¥¶Ë¥¶Êà∑ÈÄöÂ∏∏ÊòØ‰æõÂ∫îÂïÜÊàñÂÆ¢Êà∑ÁöÑÂØπË¥¶Ë¥¶Êà∑„ÄÇ

‚ÄúÁßëÁõÆÁ±ªÂûã‚Äù‰∏≠ÔºåÊèê‰æõ‰∫Ü‰∏âÁßç‰∏çÂêåÁöÑÁßëÁõÆÁ±ªÂûã„ÄÇÈíàÂØπÁõ¥Êé•Ê≥ïÁé∞ÈáëÊµÅÈáèË°®Ôºö
‚Ä¢Áé∞ÈáëÁßëÁõÆ‚ÄìËØ∑ÈÖçÁΩÆÊî∂‰ªòÊ¨æÂá≠ËØÅ‰∏≠ÁöÑÁé∞Èáë/Èì∂Ë°åÂ≠òÊ¨æÁ±ªÁßëÁõÆ
‚Ä¢ÊäµÈîÄÁßëÁõÆ‚ÄìËØ∑ÈÖçÁΩÆÊî∂‰ªòÊ¨æÂá≠ËØÅ‰∏≠ÈíàÂØπÁé∞Èáë/Èì∂Ë°åÂ≠òÊ¨æÁßëÁõÆÁöÑÊäµÈîÄÁßëÁõÆÔºå‰æãÂ¶ÇÔºöÂ∫îÊî∂„ÄÅÂ∫î‰ªòË¥¶Ê¨æÁßëÁõÆ
‚Ä¢ÂèëÁ•®ÁßëÁõÆ‚ÄìËØ∑ÈÖçÁΩÆ‰∏éÊî∂‰ªòÊ¨æÂá≠ËØÅÊúâÊ∏ÖË¥¶ÂÖ≥Á≥ªÁöÑÂèëÁ•®Âá≠ËØÅ‰∏≠ÁöÑÊäµÈîÄÁßëÁõÆÔºå‰æãÂ¶ÇÔºöË¥πÁî®„ÄÅÂ∫ìÂ≠ò„ÄÅÊî∂ÂÖ•ÁßëÁõÆÁ≠â

Ê≥®ÔºöÂú®Áõ¥Êé•Ê≥ïÁé∞ÈáëÊµÅÈáèË°®‰∏≠ÔºåÂ¶ÇÊÇ®ÈúÄË¶Å‰ª•ËøΩÊ∫ØÂá≠ËØÅÈìæÊ∏ÖË¥¶ÂÖ≥Á≥ªÊù•Êé®ÂØºÁé∞ÈáëÊµÅÁöÑÁî®ÈÄîÔºåËØ∑ÂêåÊó∂ÈÖçÁΩÆ‚ÄúÁé∞ÈáëÁßëÁõÆ‚Äù„ÄÅ‚ÄúÊäµÈîÄÁßëÁõÆ‚ÄùÂíå‚ÄúÂèëÁ•®ÁßëÁõÆ‚Äù„ÄÇ
Â¶ÇÈíàÂØπÂçïÁ∫ØÁöÑÊÄªË¥¶Âá≠ËØÅÊé®ÂØºÁé∞ÈáëÊµÅÁöÑÁî®ÈÄîÔºå‰æãÂ¶ÇCr Èì∂Ë°åÂ≠òÊ¨æDr Ë¥πÁî®Ôºå‰∏çÂ≠òÂú®Â∫îÊî∂Â∫î‰ªòÁßëÁõÆÁöÑÊ∏ÖË¥¶ÔºåËØ∑ÂêåÊó∂ÈÖçÁΩÆ‚ÄúÁé∞ÈáëÁßëÁõÆ‚ÄùÂíå‚ÄúÊäµÈîÄÁßëÁõÆ‚ÄùÂç≥ÂèØ„ÄÇ

entry.title: Re: Standard bank file format "JP_ZENGINKYO" does not out...
entry.content: Hi @Chris1973, thank you for your answer. The payment method I used was "T" (Domestic bank transfer) which goes with JP_ZENGINKYO and all other configuration was also compatible with each other. The problem was that when creating House bank, I accidentally forget to enter company code for "payment medium general data". That leaded to the fact that all concerned information was available but could not be extracted into the file. I updated the problem in case of reference for other users encountering the same errors. Again, thank you a lot for active contribution and comments.

entry.title: Is simultaneous, automatic GR/GI possible in the case of co-products?
entry.content:
Hello everyone! I hope I could post this question here even though it would be my first post.

In CO11N, I am trying to confirm production order operations of my selected finished product. I had also tried to conduct automatic goods issuance (of HALB/ROH) within the same transaction.

I went ahead and already tried to conduct simultaneous goods movement of my HALB/ROH through movement type 261, and FERT through movement type 101 but eventually got an error specifying that production orders with co-product headers cannot be simultaneously process automatic GR/GI.

Error code: MILL-PC192

For my next step, I simply proceeded to do the following:

„ÉªConducted partial confirmation of the production order

„ÉªConducted goods issuance of my finished products' components

„ÉªConducted goods receipt of my finished product

I apologize for not being able to provide any actual pictures with regard to this, but does anyone have a different workaround for this error code (from their own experience)?

entry.title: Re: Standard bank file format "JP_ZENGINKYO" does not out...
entry.content: Hi @RaymondGiuseppi, thanks to your document, I already can solve the problem. Thank you a lot, it is really informative and helpful document to refer for any bank file problems.

entry.title: UnwRAPping the ABAP RAP Runtime: Inside the Engine & Transactional Buffers
entry.content:
Background

Having worked with ABAP RAP for over quite some years now and after taking quite a few technical interviews, what I observed from my experience is that many developers still struggle to fully understand what happens inside the ABAP RAP runtime ‚Äî especially around transactional buffering, EML execution, and commit/rollback behaviours.
Hence setting the context of this blog.

‚û°Ô∏è‚û°Ô∏è‚û°Ô∏è‚û°Ô∏è‚û°Ô∏è‚û°Ô∏è‚û°Ô∏è‚û°Ô∏è‚û°Ô∏è‚û°Ô∏è‚û°Ô∏è‚û°Ô∏è‚û°Ô∏è‚û°Ô∏è‚û°Ô∏è‚û°Ô∏è‚û°Ô∏è‚û°Ô∏è‚û°Ô∏è‚û°Ô∏è‚û°Ô∏è‚û°Ô∏è‚¨ÖÔ∏è‚¨ÖÔ∏è‚¨ÖÔ∏è‚¨ÖÔ∏è‚¨ÖÔ∏è‚¨ÖÔ∏è‚¨ÖÔ∏è‚¨ÖÔ∏è‚¨ÖÔ∏è‚¨ÖÔ∏è‚¨ÖÔ∏è‚¨ÖÔ∏è‚¨ÖÔ∏è‚¨ÖÔ∏è‚¨ÖÔ∏è‚¨ÖÔ∏è

Introduction

The ABAP RESTful Application Programming Model (RAP) is the foundation for building modern, cloud-ready, and transactional applications on SAP BTP ABAP Environment and SAP S/4HANA.

Crucial to its understanding is about its runtime and hence in this blog, we will touch upon and break down the following concepts in an ntuitive way:

  • RAP Runtime Flow
  • RAP Transactional Buffers (Draft & Active)

Let‚Äôs start from the foundation.

‚û°Ô∏è‚û°Ô∏è‚û°Ô∏è‚û°Ô∏è‚û°Ô∏è‚û°Ô∏è‚û°Ô∏è‚û°Ô∏è‚û°Ô∏è‚û°Ô∏è‚û°Ô∏è‚û°Ô∏è‚û°Ô∏è‚û°Ô∏è‚û°Ô∏è‚û°Ô∏è‚û°Ô∏è‚û°Ô∏è‚û°Ô∏è‚û°Ô∏è‚û°Ô∏è‚û°Ô∏è‚¨ÖÔ∏è‚¨ÖÔ∏è‚¨ÖÔ∏è‚¨ÖÔ∏è‚¨ÖÔ∏è‚¨ÖÔ∏è‚¨ÖÔ∏è‚¨ÖÔ∏è‚¨ÖÔ∏è‚¨ÖÔ∏è‚¨ÖÔ∏è‚¨ÖÔ∏è‚¨ÖÔ∏è‚¨ÖÔ∏è‚¨ÖÔ∏è‚¨ÖÔ∏è

ABAP RAP Runtime ‚Äî The Invisible Engine

When you build a transactional application with RAP, a lot happens behind the scenes in what we call the RAP runtime engine. It‚Äôs ‚Äúinvisible‚Äù because you rarely write code for many of its steps ‚Äî but knowing what it does is key to debug & optimise.

The RAP runtime is responsible for orchestrating everything that happens when you call an action, modify data, run validation/determinations, or commit a business object.

Key responsibilities of RAP runtime:

  • Provides draft handling
  • Maintains transactional buffers
  • Runs determinations/validations/actions in the right order
  • Ensures ACID properties for business transactions
  • Consolidates errors, warnings, and messages through REPORTED structure
  • Writes data to the database only after commit

The most important thing to understand: RAP never directly updates the DB during EML calls. Everything goes into the RAP transactional buffer first.

Here‚Äôs how the runtime engine typically handles a transactional request (e.g., modify, create, action on a BO):

  1. Receive Request
    The service binding/OData call enters the RAP runtime. The runtime frameworks dispatch this to the correct BO implementation.
  2. Interaction Phase: Loading & Buffering
    • If the request references existing data, the runtime loads the existing BO instance into the transactional buffer.
    • If it‚Äôs new data, buffer is prepared accordingly with new instance(s).
    • All modifications (via EML) are made against the buffer, not directly the database.
    • This phase may include edit/draft handling, business logic, change of states.
  3. Save Sequence Trigger
    Once the interaction phase completes (i.e., no more immediate edit tasks), the runtime triggers the Save Sequence.
  4. Consistency Checks & Late Logic
    • The runtime runs final determinations, validations to ensure data integrity.
    • Any failures here cause rollback of buffer (no DB write).
    • Then key generating logic (late numbering etc) happens if required.
  5. Database Write & Buffer Clean-up
    • The buffered changes are persisted and the transactional buffer is cleaned up.

The runtime returns results (FAILED / REPORTED / MAPPED) to the caller.
The runtime can also be further divided into Standard Operations and Non-standard Operations Runtime based on the operation types.
Source : help.sap.com

‚û°Ô∏è‚û°Ô∏è‚û°Ô∏è‚û°Ô∏è‚û°Ô∏è‚û°Ô∏è‚û°Ô∏è‚û°Ô∏è‚û°Ô∏è‚û°Ô∏è‚û°Ô∏è‚û°Ô∏è‚û°Ô∏è‚û°Ô∏è‚û°Ô∏è‚û°Ô∏è‚û°Ô∏è‚û°Ô∏è‚û°Ô∏è‚û°Ô∏è‚û°Ô∏è‚û°Ô∏è‚¨ÖÔ∏è‚¨ÖÔ∏è‚¨ÖÔ∏è‚¨ÖÔ∏è‚¨ÖÔ∏è‚¨ÖÔ∏è‚¨ÖÔ∏è‚¨ÖÔ∏è‚¨ÖÔ∏è‚¨ÖÔ∏è‚¨ÖÔ∏è‚¨ÖÔ∏è‚¨ÖÔ∏è‚¨ÖÔ∏è‚¨ÖÔ∏è‚¨ÖÔ∏è

ABAP RAP Transactional Buffers

The ABAP RESTful Application Programming Model (RAP) does not introduce its own LUW concept, but uses the rules and concepts of the SAP LUW and thus does inherent checks ensure that your application is consistent and stable, also when more than one BO is involved.

RAP uses an internal transactional buffer (in-memory layer) to temporarily hold all data modifications.

It is the key ‚Äúscratch‚Äêpad‚Äù where all modifications happen before anything goes to the database. Think of it like a workspace for your BO operations.

Every operation (create, update, delete, action) targets an instance in the buffer first. The buffer is internal to RAP runtime ‚Äî you don‚Äôt explicitly manage it, you just use EML and commit/rollback.

Why it matters

  • It ensures isolation: multiple requests don‚Äôt interfere until commit.
  • It provides a stage for determinations/validations before final write.
  • It allows draft mode: you can work on data in draft buffer without touching active DB immediately.
  • It ensures you can rollback if something fails without partial DB updates ‚Äî ACID in practise.

Here‚Äôs how you visualise it:

 

Buffer Behaviour in Different Modes:

There are two types of buffers Draft Buffer/Draft Runtime & Active Transactional Buffer. Let‚Äôs break them down.

 

  • Active Transactional Buffer ‚Äì The In-Memory DB-Staging Area

The Active Transactional Buffer is used when you work on active instances (not in draft mode).
This handles all temporary changes for active data until COMMIT ENTITIES.No draft tables involved.

When It Is Used

  • When your BO is not draft-enabled.
  • When your BO is draft-enabled but you are working on active instances (e.g., %is_draft = 00).
  • When triggering actions that operate on active data.

What Happens on COMMIT

At COMMIT, RAP takes all pending changes from the transactional buffer, runs validations and determinations, executes the save sequence, and finally writes everything to the database.

 

  • Draft Buffer aka Draft Runtime‚Äì Your Temporary Workspace

The Draft Buffer is a staging area inside the RAP runtime that stores unsaved, in-progress work of a user managed by Draft Runtime.

Since RESTful applications require a constant stateless communication with the backend to prevent that transient data is lost when a user session ends, drafts are essential.

Here, for new-draft & edit-draft instances, data gets updates in Draft Database tables only upon COMMIT ENTITIES.

Only on ACTIVATE, it gets converted into Active Instance in a Active Transactional Buffer and then gets persisted to database table on COMMIT ENTITIES.

When It Is Used

  • When you run MODIFY ENTITIES ... ENTITY <X> CREATE with draft modifier,
  • When you trigger draft actions:
  • When you read draft-specific elements.

What Happens on COMMIT

At activation, RAP takes the draft buffer data, runs validations and determinations, executes the save sequence, deletes the draft, and promotes the changes to active database records

The One-Liner Summary:

  •  Active Mode: COMMIT ENTITIES takes the delta from the transactional buffer ‚Üí validates ‚Üí determines ‚Üí writes to DB ‚Üí commits ‚Üí clears buffer.
  •  Draft Mode: ACTIVATE  promotes data to active instance ‚Üí COMMIT ENTITIES runs the full save sequence ‚Üí deletes draft ‚Üí commits.

Source: help.sap.com

‚û°Ô∏è‚û°Ô∏è‚û°Ô∏è‚û°Ô∏è‚û°Ô∏è‚û°Ô∏è‚û°Ô∏è‚û°Ô∏è‚û°Ô∏è‚û°Ô∏è‚û°Ô∏è‚û°Ô∏è‚û°Ô∏è‚û°Ô∏è‚û°Ô∏è‚û°Ô∏è‚û°Ô∏è‚û°Ô∏è‚û°Ô∏è‚û°Ô∏è‚û°Ô∏è‚û°Ô∏è‚¨ÖÔ∏è‚¨ÖÔ∏è‚¨ÖÔ∏è‚¨ÖÔ∏è‚¨ÖÔ∏è‚¨ÖÔ∏è‚¨ÖÔ∏è‚¨ÖÔ∏è‚¨ÖÔ∏è‚¨ÖÔ∏è‚¨ÖÔ∏è‚¨ÖÔ∏è‚¨ÖÔ∏è‚¨ÖÔ∏è‚¨ÖÔ∏è‚¨ÖÔ∏è

What about ROLLBACK ?

1. Discards entire buffer
‚Üí The runtime clears all staged changes.

2. No DB write/rollback
‚Üí Nothing is persisted/rolled back to/from the database.

3. No further validations/actions
‚Üí All remaining processing is immediately stopped.

4. Restores consistent state
‚Üí System returns to a clean, stable state.

 

‚û°Ô∏è‚û°Ô∏è‚û°Ô∏è‚û°Ô∏è‚û°Ô∏è‚û°Ô∏è‚û°Ô∏è‚û°Ô∏è‚û°Ô∏è‚û°Ô∏è‚û°Ô∏è‚û°Ô∏è‚û°Ô∏è‚û°Ô∏è‚û°Ô∏è‚û°Ô∏è‚û°Ô∏è‚û°Ô∏è‚û°Ô∏è‚û°Ô∏è‚û°Ô∏è‚¨ÖÔ∏è‚¨ÖÔ∏è‚¨ÖÔ∏è‚¨ÖÔ∏è‚¨ÖÔ∏è‚¨ÖÔ∏è‚¨ÖÔ∏è‚¨ÖÔ∏è‚¨ÖÔ∏è‚¨ÖÔ∏è‚¨ÖÔ∏è‚¨ÖÔ∏è‚¨ÖÔ∏è‚¨ÖÔ∏è‚¨ÖÔ∏è‚¨ÖÔ∏è

Conclusion

If you‚Äôve reached this far, you may now have a clear inside-out view of how ABAP RAP‚Äôs runtime and transactional buffers really work.

To wrap up, the runtime is all about buffers, orchestration, and guaranteed consistency.

Understanding this invisible engine not only helps you debug confidently but also helps you design cleaner, safer, more predictable business objects.

If this blog helped even a little bit in strengthening that foundation, then mission accomplished !

Keep exploring, keep building ! üôÇ

 

Regards,
Subhajit

entry.title: How to display Microsoft documents along with PDF and Images in SAP UI5 application
entry.content:
Overview:

Displaying Microsoft document type DOCX, PPT, XSLX etc. along with PDF and Image in SAP UI5/Fiori Application.

Business Requirement:

In one of my project, I have requirement where customer want to display all the attachments like docx, pdf, or pptx etc. inside fiori application. So, the user does not need to switch to different application on the system to view documents.

By default, Fiori provides preview capabilities for PDFs and images, but it does not support Microsoft file formats. But Since the customer needs to preview these file types directly inside the Fiori app, I explored alternatives and determined that the Apryse WebViewer SDK is capable of meeting this requirement

Note: This has additional licensing which customer procured in our case. There are few other libraries which you can utilize based on your requirement.

Step by Step Implementation:

  1. Create an MTA project and add a Fiori application to it.
  2. Now, we need to set up the webviewer sdk in the project. Open terminal from fiori application directory and run command npm i @pdftron/webviewer.
  3. Create a lib folder inside webapp and copy the core, ui, webviewer.min.js from node_modules/@pdftron/webviewer/public.

4. For our project, We created html div container which will display the document inside webviewer when user clicks on LoadDocument button.

5. In Controller, on onLoadDocumentPress, we will initialize and load webviewer like shown in below image

6. Open the terminal and run the command npm run start .

 

Note: License would be required to remove the watermark from the document.

Summary:

WebViewer supports viewing multiple document types, such as PDF, PPTX, and DOCX. In the example above, the document is rendered by converting a Base64-encoded string into a blob, but WebViewer also allows loading documents directly using a file path.

For more information, you can refer following link

Detailed code is available on github repo.

entry.title: Top issues faced during Worker Integration in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition.
entry.content:
1. Cost Center is missing or is not reflected in Manage Workforce application.

Follow the below KBA: 3555420 - Missing Cost Center in Manage Workforce application after replicating via MDI to S4 - SAP for Me

2. How to delete the work agreement or block a work agreement of an employee?

Blocking of work agreement can be done by scheduling an ILM process. You can do that by following this blog: How schedule ILM Job

3. How to create multiple work agreements for a worker via Import option in Manage Workforce app.

Currently it is not supported to create multiple work agreements via import functionality in Manage Workforce application. You can use SOAP API for mass creation in such scenario.

3563776 - Import Multiple work Agreements with Manage Workforce app - SAP for Me

4.  When creating or updating worker data in the Manage Workforce app, the following error is generated.

Mapping for the payment method is not found. Parameters: XX,XX,XX,.
Message no. FAP_H2R007

This error occurs when the mapping for the payment method which is specified could not be found by the system. To resolve this, follow the below KBA:

3058691 - Payment Method Not Found Error When Creating or Updating Worker Data - SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition - SAP for Me

5. Number <CENTRAL_PERSON> is already assigned to partner <BP number> for ID type HCM033", Message no. R1477

According to the New BP model, supplier role should be assigned to Employment BP and not Employee BP. This error message occurs when the supplier role has been manually added to Employee BP. Follow the below KBA to resolve this:

3266815 - Error Message "Number <CENTRAL_PERSON> is already assigned to partner <BP number> for ID type HCM033" Displayed After Replication - SAP for Me

6. How to create Supplier or Customer roles in BP?

To create a supplier role in S/4 system, you need to send payment information (Bank, IBAN etc) in the payload.

To create the customer role, check this documentation.

7. How gender information of the worker is stored in S/4 system.

Gender is personal, sensitive data belonging to an employee. Since SAP S/4HANA Cloud doesn‚Äôt include a process that needs this information, it isn‚Äôt replicated. 

For more information, go through this KBA: 3217150 - Employee replication excludes the "Gender code". - SAP for Me

8. How to set up Service Cost Level (SCL)?

To set-up SCL, follow this blog.

9. How to create a worker, without a business user?

During worker replication, if the username field is passed in the payload, a business user will be created in the S/4 system. To resolve this issue, follow the below KBA:

3563848 - How to create a worker without creating a business user. - SAP for Me

10. "Workforce person does not have active job details" or "Business Partner Role Code is mandatory for creation."

Job Details in Work Agreements are Inactive. At least one Job details of a work agreement should be active. Follow the below KBA to resolve this error:

3581416 - Error while updating or creating of the Worker data - SAP for Me

entry.title: Steps to include a new system to an existing STMS Domain controller.
entry.content:
Introduction

In any SAP landscape, managing system transports efficiently is critical to maintaining consistency across environments. The SAP Transport Management System (STMS) plays a central role in controlling and moving changes between systems such as Development (DEV), Quality (QAS), and Production (PRD).

There are few blogs and guides available on STMS configuration ‚Äî from setting up domain controllers to defining transport routes. However, this blog takes a slightly different perspective. Instead of covering the standard setup process, I‚Äôll focus on a real-world scenario: adding a new system to an existing STMS domain controller.

In this example, we‚Äôll walk through how to integrate an additional Quality system into an existing three-tier landscape (DEV ‚Üí QAS ‚Üí PRD). This will effectively extend the current landscape and demonstrate how to configure transport routes, verify connectivity, and ensure smooth synchronization across all systems.

Whether you‚Äôre expanding your SAP environment or fine-tuning your transport architecture, this step-by-step guide will help you add a new system seamlessly to your existing STMS configuration.

In this blog post, we are going to see how we can add an additional new quality system in between DEV and QAS in the TR route and how we can create target groups.

Existing configuration is DS4(Dev)---QS4(Quality)---PS4(production and also domain controller).

Post adding the new system, the TR route will be DS4(Dev)-----QS3(new system)-------QS4(QA)----PS4(domain controller).

Prerequisites

Before starting the configuration, ensure the following prerequisites are met:

  1. The new system is fully set up ‚Äî The SAP installation and post-installation activities (such as profile configuration, instance setup, and client creation) are complete.
  2. RFC connectivity is established ‚Äî The new system can communicate with the existing domain controller via trusted RFC connections.
  3. Transport directories are shared and accessible ‚Äî The /usr/sap/trans directory is mounted and accessible from the new system and all systems in the landscape.
  4. User authorizations are in place ‚Äî The user performing this configuration has the necessary SAP Basis and STMS administration rights.
  5. Existing STMS domain is active ‚Äî Verify that the domain controller (typically DEV) is configured and operational.
  6. TMSADM user password must be maintained in all the systems (in client 000). The password of TMSADM needs to be consistent within the whole transport domain.
  7. Access of DDIC user in client 000.

Delete the existing STMS config in the new system:

If your new SAP system already has an STMS (Transport Management System) configuration, you‚Äôll first need to remove it before joining an existing STMS domain controller. This ensures there are no conflicts or duplicate entries when connecting to the central landscape.

Follow these steps to clean up the existing TMS configuration from a standalone system:

  1. Log in to the master client (000) of the new system (for example, QS3). Open transaction STMS and make sure you‚Äôre logged into the domain controller.
  2. Go to transaction SE06. Under the section Database Copy or Database Migration, click Perform Post-Installation Actions, and confirm with Yes.

  1. When prompted to select the source system for a database copy, choose No.
  2. In the next dialog, you‚Äôll be asked whether to delete the TMS configuration ‚Äî select Yes.
  3. Confirm the following prompts by choosing Yes until you see a message confirming that the STMS configuration has been successfully deleted.

Once the existing configuration is removed, your system is ready to be added to the main STMS domain controller.

Steps to include the new system to an existing STMS DC

Login to the master client of the new system (in this case QS3-000), and go to STMS. System will give a prompt to add the system to transport domain. In this case we want QS3 to be added to PS4 domain, but in the below screenshot, its showing by default SS4(another system),  click on ‚Äúother configurations button as shown below.

Give the Domain controller server details that you want the new system to be added as shown below and give save.

Enter the password of TMSADM in Domain controller client

After giving password, QS3(new SID) will be added to domain controller. Now the next step is to login to domain controller client and approve the system.

Login to Domain controller client, go to STMS‚ÄîOverview‚ÄîSystems, check QS3(new SID), its waiting to be included. It‚Äôs not active yet.

Click QS3---Click Menu‚ÄîSAP systems‚ÄîApprove.

Click Yes and you will get one more pop up to distribute the configuration, click yes, after that, system will become active.

Adding the new system to the TR route

Login to Domain controller--- Go to STMS‚Äîclick on transport routes

Follow the below step and select graphical editor

Click on Edit

 

Select transport layer ZDS4 and Transport layer SAP and delete those lines

Drag the new SID QS3 down and Go to Edit

After selecting ‚ÄúAdd transport route‚Äù, click on DS4 and draw a line to QS3

You will get a pop up select ZDS4 transport layer and make sure you are selecting consolidation route.

Again repeat same steps and create a route for SAP transport layer.

Create a transport route between QS3 and QS4, this time it will be a delivery route.

After completing this step, click YES

You will get this pop up click yes

Distribute and activate the changes.

Check the activation log for any errors or warnings.
